citing_paper_authors: Rion, Snow | Sushant, Prakash | Daniel, Jurafsky | Andrew Y., Ng
raw_text: In this work we focus on two datasets of hand-labeled sense groupings for WordNet: first, a dataset of sense groupings over nouns, verbs, and adjectives provided as part of the SENSEVAL-2 English lexical sample WSD task (Kilgarriff, 2001), and second, a corpus-driven map ping of nouns and verbs in WordNet 2.1 to the Omega Ontology (Philpot et al, 2005), produced as part of the ONTONOTES project (Hovy et al, 2006)
clean_text: In this work we focus on two datasets of hand-labeled sense groupings for WordNet: first, a dataset of sense groupings over nouns, verbs, and adjectives provided as part of the SENSEVAL-2 English lexical sample WSD task (Kilgarriff, 2001), and second, a corpus-driven mapping of nouns and verbs in WordNet 2.1 to the Omega Ontology (Philpot et al, 2005), produced as part of the ONTONOTES project (Hovy et al, 2006).

clean_text: We then merged the word alignment annotation with the TreeBank and PropBank annotation of Ontonotes4.0 (Hovy et al, 2006), which includes a wide array of data sources like broadcast news, news wire, magazine, web text, etc.

citing_paper_authors: Anna, Rumshisky
raw_text: In the OntoNotes project (Hovyetal., 2006), annotators use small-scale corpus analysis to create sense inventories derived by grouping together WordNet senses, with the procedure restricted to maintain 90% inter-annotator agreement. Importantly, most standard WSD resources contain no information about the clarity of distinctions between different senses in the sense inventory
clean_text: In the OntoNotes project (Hovy et al., 2006), annotators use small-scale corpus analysis to create sense inventories derived by grouping together WordNet senses, with the procedure restricted to maintain 90% inter-annotator agreement.
